newsitem.title: PANAMA: New Panama Canal law could be ready this month.
newsitem.headline: New Panama Canal law could be ready this month.

text.p: A new law to govern operations of the Panama Canal in the next century should be passed by Congress this month, a top government official said Thursday.

"Congress has already passed the first draft of the Panama Canal Organic Law. Final passage should come this month," Jorge Ritter, head of the Panama Canal transition team, told the Foreign Press Association.

The law will create the Panama Canal Authority and replace the Panama Canal Commission (PCC) and all U.S. laws. It will take effect once control of the Panama Canal turns over from the United States to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999, he said.

Ritter said the transition team, which has been working with the PCC on the text, recommended that the law deny the canal's roughly 9,000 labor force the right to strike. "This is to assure users that the canal is not interrupted," he said.
The law would also address environmental issues to ensure the canal's 805,000-acre (330,000-hectare) watershed is protected.
